channel.title: Climate Change Impacts
channel.description: Updated Climate Change Impacts content from the US Environmental Protection Agency

item.title: Climate Change and Health Factsheets
item.description:
Understanding the threats that climate change poses to human health can help us work together to lower risks and be prepared. Climate change threatens human health, including mental health, and access to clean air, safe drinking water, nutritious food, and shelter.

All Americans, at some point in their lives, are vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. Some people are more affected by climate change than others because of factors like where they live; their age, health, income, and occupation; and how they go about their day-to-day life.

The fact sheets on this page are part of a series of communications materials to highlight the health impacts of climate change at different stages of life and for certain populations of concern. Vea las hojas informativas en español.

  • Stages of Life (PDF)(1 pg, 1 MB)
  • Children (PDF)(4 pp, 3 MB)
  • Environmental Justice (PDF)(4 pp, 3 MB)
  • Indigenous Populations (PDF)(4 pp, 2 MB)
  • Occupational Groups (PDF)(4 pp, 4 MB)
  • Older Adults (PDF)(4 pp, 4 MB)
  • Older Adults (large font version) (PDF)(4 pp, 2 MB)
  • People with Disabilities (PDF)(4 pp, 4 MB)
  • People with Disabilities (large font version) (PDF)(4 pp, 4 MB)
  • People with Existing Health Conditions (PDF)(4 pp, 1 MB)
  • Pregnant Women (PDF)(4 pp, 2 MB)
  • Stages of Life (plain text version) (PDF)(2 pp, 564 K)
  • Children (11"x17" version) (PDF)(2 pp, 5 MB)
  • Environmental Justice (11"x17" version) (PDF)(2 pp, 7 MB)
  • Indigenous Populations (11"x17" version) (PDF)(2 pp, 3 MB)
  • Occupational Groups (11"x17" version) (PDF)(2 pp, 5 MB)
  • Older Adults (11"x17" version) (PDF)(2 pp, 5 MB)
  • People with Disabilities (11"x17" version) (PDF)(2 pp, 6 MB)
  • People with Existing Health Conditions (11"x17" version) (PDF)(2 pp, 2 MB)
  • Pregnant Women (11"x17" version) (PDF)(2 pp, 4 MB)
item.dc:creator: tnayem

item.title: Communicating Vulnerabilities to Climate Change: Existing Health Conditions
item.description:
EPA has developed communication materials that summarize key points from the U.S. Climate and Health Assessment on eight different populations that are disproportionately affected by climate change impacts. The agency is providing these materials for use and modification for anyone seeking to communicate the health impacts of climate change to a range of audiences.

  • How to Use these Materials and Summary Points: Existing Health Conditions (.docx)(7 pp, 1 MB)
  • Customizable Powerpoint Presentation: Existing Health Conditions (.ppt)(10 pp, 2 MB)
  • Shareable graphics (.jpg): [550x375] [1024x512] [1200x630]

See the People with Existing Health Conditions factsheets below. See communications materials for other populations of concern. For questions or assistance, please email climatehealth@epa.gov.

  • Climate Change and the Health of People with Existing Medical Conditions (PDF)(2 pp, 1 MB)
  • El Cambio Climático y la Salud de las Personas con Trastornos Crónicos (PDF)(4 pp, 1 MB)
  • Printable (11"x17") Version: Climate Change and the Health of People with Existing Medical Conditions (PDF)(2 pp, 2 MB)
item.dc:creator: tnayem

item.title: Communicating Vulnerabilities to Climate Change: Indigenous Populations
item.description:
EPA has developed communication materials that summarize key points from the U.S. Climate and Health Assessment on eight different populations that are disproportionately affected by climate change impacts. Stakeholders are encouraged to use or modify these materials to strengthen their conversations about climate change and health impacts to vulnerable populations.

  • How to Use these Materials and Summary Points: Indigenous Populations (.docx)(6 pp, 734 K)
  • Customizable Powerpoint Presentation: Indigenous Populations (.ppt)(10 pp, 1 MB)
  • Shareable graphics (.jpg): [550x375] [1024x512] [1200x630]

See the Indigenous Populations factsheets below. See communications materials for other populations of concern. For questions or assistance, please email climatehealth@epa.gov.

  • Climate Change and the Health of Indigenous Populations (PDF)(4 pp, 2 MB)
  • El Cambio Climático y la Salud de las Poblaciones Indígenas (PDF)(4 pp, 2 MB)
  • Printable (11"x17") Version: Climate Change and the Health of Indigenous Populations (PDF)(2 pp, 3 MB)
